Entry.1: At Bernefay at A.I.S. The weather is still wet and dull and in no wise different from that which we have been having all along lately.
Entry.2: Today I was warned to go on leave on 27th inst. Saw George Wilkie this afternoon, he is camped over the road.
Entry.3: I with a few others move back to the unit at Buire which is just as desolate as ever
Entry.4: Tonight a party of us went to see the "Shrapnel" at Merricourt and enjoyed a very good variety show.
Entry.5: Still at Buire where the weather lately has been fine and nice. I notice some shelling on a hill a couple of miles away but I have no idea whether it is our practice or Fritz.
Entry.6: A big bombardment is current to the left towards Thiepval way and rumours are rife as to an advance and prisoners.
Entry.7: At the Merricourt show again but the performers are not as good as last time.
Entry.8: Still at Buire but the fine weather has gone and given way to windy and cold days and nights
Entry.11: This morning we found the ground covered to a depth of four inches or more with snow and we had much enjoyment snowballing. This afternoon we all turned out on a hare hunt over the hills at the back and after an hours best of fun we got one hare. Many managed to get through our cordon.
Entry.12: Still snowing. We had another hunt this afternoon with same results as yesterday.
Entry.13: The ground is still white with snow. It is rumoured that we move soon to a sector of this front.
Entry.14: The weather is still bitterly cold and today we moved to Albert where we were billeted in the old girls school. We are going into the line near Martinfuchs and forming an H.D.S. at Bazentin le Petit.
Entry.15: At Albert still but weather still freezing. Fritz has shelled the town today but I have heard of no casualties. I go on leave on 29th so cant see much use in going up to the line.
Entry.16: March from Albert to Bazentin ADS & from there up to the line on the left of Flers & in front of High Wood. We came up through Contalmaison & past Casualty Corner but law & order prevail there now so the place cannot be recognised. Things are quiet here but the division’s not in yet but comes in tomorrow. The snow is still on the ground which is frozen hard.
Entry.17: Ground is still snow covered and frozen hard which makes almost all shells burst. I move back to Edwards post this afternoon in anticipation of going on leave.
Entry.18: On ration fatigue to Bazentin A.D.S. It is rumoured that leave has been suspended on account of traffic congestion.
Entry.19: Came back to Bazentin in anticipation of leave but find it suspended as I said yesterday. The British are taking more front from the French.
Entry.20: H H S at Bazentin still waiting for leave but nothing is known of its re-opening.
Entry.21: Still waiting. Nothing of importance has occurred lately.
Entry.22: Weather beautifully fine with bright sunny days and clear moonlit nights, but very cold.
Entry.23: Tonight I visited Pozieres & had a look over the old ground. Everything is clean and orderly but the graveyard has been greatly augmented. The night is moonlit and the snow still covers the ground. Battery of 9.2 is by our old aid Post.
Entry.24: The weather is still fine but freezing cold and papers say that this is the coldest weather for many years. Fritz shells about us nightly & today about a quarter of a mile up the valley.
Entry.25:
Leave passes arrive & in the best of spirits. Percy James & I move to D.H.Q. to report. We have to report again at 6pm.

Leave has been postponed again & I have to return to the unit very disappointed.
Entry.26: Bemoaning my fate of yesterday. Rumours of a big raid are current.
Entry.28: went over on a raid which was an utter failure. Of the 100 who made up the party 75 per cent; were casualties. Our HDS is very inconvenient & our colonel incapable.
Entry.29: Went for a walk to Edwards post to show Perkins round. A stunt is expected shortly & he is in charge of reserve squads. Came back through High Wood where many tanks are stranded & many monuments erected to those who took part in the fighting there. The tanks are being cleaned in anticipation of being used again. No word of leave yet.
Entry.30: Tonight we were warned the Fritz intended bombing all rail heads.
Entry.31: This morning I was awakened by bursting bombs, machine gun fire & anti-aircraft firing. Fritz caught a big ammunition dump & from reports he caused considerable damage. Great clouds of smoke roll over the hills a few miles away, and the explosions are almost continuous.
Entry.32: Everything on the front is very quiet & casualties few. The good clear weather has gone & the thaw commenced with the result everything is muddy again. However the days are comparatively warm when the late frosty weather is considered.
Entry.33: Last night the long expected attack was made by the
Entry.34: and wild rumours are current as to the result. The objective was gained without much opposition and it is hinted the Fritz has begun a big retreat. The infantry say that he cannot be found. Many casualties are coming through.
Entry.35:
Good progress is still being made up the line and casualties are coming in.

Duncan Robertson was wounded in the neck & shoulder last night.

Lately I have been ill, running a temp. & aches in legs. Three times in twelve days I have been so & the major says it’s trench fever.
Entry.36: The papers now confirm the above advance of two miles on an eleven mile front. Le Baque, & Marlancourt fell to the Australians who hold from Guedecourt to Le Sars. Casualties have slackened off & the distance from Baupume is only 1800 yards.
Entry.37:
Fighting in the open is now in progress.

The colonel & Reg Shergold were wounded to-day, the former in the chest & the latter in the leg. The colonel is not expected to live & he is not to be moved.
Entry.38: The colonel died this morning. The weather is rough & March winds are going in full swing.
Entry.39: Ill again. I have been put on quinine daily. Open fighting still continues. Move back to Fricourt Farm in advance party.
Entry.40: Balance of unit minus bearers move back to Fricourt Farm. The bearers have been up the line since
Entry.41: without a break & through bad work & weather.
Entry.42:
Still open fighting. It is said that the Germans are beginning a big retreating movement.

No news of leave.
Entry.43: At 4pm Sat. Wooster asked me if I would proceed on leave to England on leave to-night. I now have my pass & am in Amiens waiting for a passenger to Bolougne from which port I will cross. Arrived here by car from Fricourt. Leave is special & only two from a division being allowed daily.
Entry.44: In London at Shaftesbury Hotel. I arrived at Bolougne from Amiens at 5.30am & after breakfast at 10.30 left on the "Onward’for Folkstone. Arrive there & entrain on S.E & C.R Coy at mid-day and arrive in London at 3 pm. Escort of three destroyers & crossing calm. The 3rd class carriages are luxurious after the French railways. To bed early after a bath.
Entry.45: Foggy to-day. Experience of travelling by the marvellous tube and omnibus. Visit bank, Houses of Parliament, Westminster Abbey and Cleopatra’s needle on the Thames embankment. "Phooclare &Co" at the Gaiety. It is like a dream to sit in clean cafes & watch a musical comedy & sleep in between sheets & hear English girls.
Entry.46: Morning service at St Pauls. In the afternoon visit Richmond on the Thames but it is wet. There are many cosy tea rooms on Richmond Hill, Cottage Teas etc.
Entry.47: This morning to Tower & Tower Bridge & have a good look round. After, Law Courts in Strand & hear Lord Chief Justice on a treason case. Hyde Park, Oxford St Rotten Row & The Serpentine this afternoon. "High Jinks" at Adelphe this evening after a walk round Picadilly Circus way. Still dream in tea rooms, cafes with music & busy streets.
Entry.48:
From Waterloo to Hampton Court, a fine run on electric train through beautiful suburbs' in Surrey. Hampton Court Palace & grounds are magnificent. Lunch at the Greyhound Hotel. Return to London via Twickenham, Teddington & Richmond & visit "Vanity Fair" a revue at the Palace during the evening. Meet Miss 
 of Wimbledon & have tea with her.
Entry.49: A walk round London, Whitehall, Strand, Picadilly, Regent St, Oxford Street, Hyde Park, Rotten Row & Marble Arch. Lunch, dinner & theatre "High Jinks" with Miss Stammer. News of the fall of Bagdad.
Entry.50:
Another walk round, Pall Mall, St James Palace, Buckingham Palace & the residential quarters at W. See the changing of the guard at the latter Palace.

H.M. Theatre "Chu Chin Chow" in evening. News of successfull British work on Ancre comes through daily. Still marvel at tubes & traffic.
Entry.51:
Visit Brighton (Sussex) & Hove & have a good look round. Hove is especially fine with broad streets & avenues. Fine water port. Hotels are particularly sumptuous.

Theatre in evening "Bric-a-Brac" with friend & a walk along the front later. Arrive in London at 1 am & after much searching find a taxi to take me home. Journey 2 hours almost. Fine day.
Entry.52: Shopping in morning. Richmond again this afternoon and get a fine panoramic view of river & country from the hill. Met friend in afternoon & go to Hammersmith to picture palace. My dream is nearing an end & on Monday return to France. News of the taking of Baupume & Russian Revolution.
Entry.53: The last day. This morning round the parks, Row, Palaces & Oxford Street. A fine walk on Sunday morn. This afternoon & evening to Richmond & along the Thames with Miss Starkie. A beautiful night with many searchlights & reflections on the river.
Entry.54: At Bolougne. Leave Victoria Street at 7.50 on a Pullman Dining Car & breakfast on journey. Beautiful ride. In a rest camp at Folkstone for a few hours and after a very stormy crossing eventually arrive here, in a neat billet for the night. News of a retreat by Fritz on a 30-40 mile front is confirmed & Cambrai & St Quentin are objectives now. Many villages captured.
Entry.55: At Abbeville en route for Amiens where we will begin to seek our units. The champagne incident. I have awakened from my dream. Many villages captured again yesterday.
Entry.56:
At Fricourt Farm again after coming from Amiens in motor cars. Ride from Abbeville to Amiens, 2nd class on a passenger. The unit moves back to Buire again tomorrow.

News of the fall of Cambrai & St Quentin & other villages but ?
Entry.57: Move back with unit to Buire again. Snowing last night & to-day but clear starlight nights. The above about Cambrai & St Quentin is incorrect.
Entry.58: At Buire which is still as bleak & windy as ever it was. Much to my disgust I am not allowed to join "B" Section at Bazentin but am put in an officers ward. No work however.
Entry.59: At Buire. Beautiful day but windy. Summer time begins at midnight, meaning clocks to be put forward one hour. Spring is noticeably coming and sky larks are becoming common again & the trees showing signs of bud.
Entry.60: Beautiful day. Like last Sunday only spent under different circumstances.
Entry.61: Raining, snowing & windy. In village of Buire met a Parisian girl who knew Brighton & Hove well. There on holidays.
Entry.62: Anniversary of our arrival in France. Celebrate it with a bottle of Haumont & drink to "next year at home". Unsettled weather.
Entry.63: Very unsettled weather. A strong rumour hath that "B" Section is to go to form part of a new ambulance in the new
Entry.65: The advance generally continues & now the line must be 20 miles away.
Entry.66: Unit equipage. Patients begin to move up to Aveluy just the other side of Albert. Last night the Germans bombed Albert, no casualties.
Entry.67: Movement in progress & to finish tomorrow. I am still at Buire but will most likely move tomorrow. The weather here is as typical as described. Rain, sleet, snow & sunshine within a few hours.
Entry.68: At Buire still but expect to move to Aveluy tomorrow. The unit moves to Bazentin again in a few days.
Entry.69: It is now decided that we will remain here & leave & join the unit at Bazentin on Friday.
Entry.70: Tomorrow Good Friday & I have visions of Sydney Station & crowded mountain trains. Had some special pastry made by an excellent French cook. Beautiful day & night.
Entry.71: Move this morning from Buire to Bazentin again. The guns can just be heard from here. Beautiful day & the sky larks are going their hardest. Move tomorrow to Bapaume.
Entry.72: Out of the Somme & once more in Pas de Calais. We moved from Bazentin via Flers, Le Roque Tilloy to Bapaume. This town now 7 miles remote from the line is in a very battered condition & is still shelled by Fritz. About the size of Albert but it seems a better class of town. Guns can be distinctly heard. The neighbouring country is not in a bad state at all. M.D.S.
Entry.73: Tonight we were ordered up to the line & we went up to the A.I.S. on the Cambrai Road. The country here is fine & not much at all marked by shellfire.
Entry.74: Early this morning we moved forward again & have been bearing all the morning. The infantry this morning took Hermes & as usual there are a good number of casualties. The bearing here is not bad but the carries are long, but over good country all cultivation paddocks. Shelling is not too severe. Our base for working is Veln & we carry to Beaumetz. Snow, rain, sleet, sunshine & wind. About 120 prisoners. Dean Fry was killed this morning on our right.
Entry.75:
Still up the line working in front of Hermes. The casualties of yesterday have all come in, in all about 300 from 2nd Batt, too great a percentage. Things are very quiet. We are now on the famous Hindenburg line & a few miles ahead are the Cambrain Hills which look very adaptable for defence. In the direction of Arras heavy bombarding is in progress & rumour says that Verny ridge has been taken with many guns & prisoners. 

Still bad & changeable weather. A German M.G. was brought in today.
Entry.76: Yesterday Harry Bladin Roger Pemberton & Lochrary were caught by a shell & Harry was badly wounded & the others got blighties. We have move back to a dugout in reserve area but another stunt is expected shortly. Another snow storm this afternoon.
Entry.77:
Nothing doing. Weather still very fickle with rain sleet snow & shine.

Mail.
Entry.78: This morning we moved to 3rd Battn R.A.P. & there built a dugout to make ourselves comfortable. In the evening, without sleeping in our dugout, we had to move up with the R.A.P. to a quarry a few hundred yards behind the outposts. There was a stunt & an advance of about 600 yards & only two casualties. Beautiful day.
Entry.79:
Another beautiful day & we in the quarry. Absolutely nothing doing. Great news comes from Arras way where apparently the push has commenced in earnest. Guns & prisoners galore.

Murcoing is a town in front of us now.
Entry.80:
Early this morning Fritz attacked our left & bombarded our pozzy very heavily but no casualties resulted. His attack was a complete failure & his casualties heavy. Ours were slight. Rotten wet weather..

Monday 16

In the attack last night one Battn on our left was beaten back & even lost four 18 pdrs (Actually 18 captured but 14 recovered intact) but in a brilliant daylight counter attack recovered the guns & 600 prisoners & all lost ground. 1200 dead Germans counted in our lines. Also last night a mine exploded in Hermies, rocking our dugout, a mile away.

The 2nd Batt relieve the
Entry.81: tonight & a new R.A.P. is to be established & we move back a hundred yards or so. Wet & miserable. Fritz brings one of our balloons down in flames.
Entry.82: Move again just behind Hermies where we built a dugout for a wagon rendezvous. Rain snow & shine.
Entry.83: Nothing at all eventful. Making dugouts in the mud and rain. Rotten wet day. It appears that the capture of Hermies is one of the greatest feats the Australians have to their credit as it was far more strongly defended than anticipated but our chaps say that Fritz does not know the value of his machine guns. Our line is very weakly held but quite strongly enough to give Fritz a very
Entry.84: bad time in his two counter attacks, one to-day in which he was worse off than that of 16th. Weather raining still. One of our planes the latest spud, accounted for two enemy baloons this morning.
Entry.85:
Move back for a couple of days spell.

Everything we hear of Fritz’s last attack points to the seriousness of it. He captured 22 guns & 16 MG’s & on the counter attack five of the 18 pdrs were found destroyed & no MG’s recovered. However his casualties were very heavy. One chap with accounted for 80 & is recommended for a V.C.
Entry.86:
Chateau at Velu built by Marquis de Covronnel in 1719.

Walk round the chateau of Velu & the grounds which once were beautiful but are now the scene of much vandalism on the part of the Germans. Here the River has its source & we bathed in it this morning.
Entry.87: Plenty of aerial work this morning & Fritz very daringly came very low & destroyed one of our balloons. The division is to be relieved tomorrow & the rumour is that we go to Belgium. This evening many aerial combats took place in which one Fritz plane was destroyed & came down in our lines. Very fine sight.
Entry.88: Relieved from the line & march back to Bapaume via Lebuquiere. Beautiful day.
Entry.89:
March back to Pozieres where we expect to stay a couple of days before we go back further. Tomorrow Anzac Day is to be celebrated & we are going to have a ‘beano’. Rather a coincidence being at Pozieres. A monument is being erected to the fallen of 1st Aust Division & many to separate battalions. 

Beautiful day.
Entry.90: Anzac Day. We had a dinner in the evening and it was followed by an impromptu concert. Beautiful day. Visit Albert.
Entry.91: In Albert again to see the "Anzac Dandies". Again a beautiful day. Expect to move shortly.
Entry.92: Beautiful day. Walk across to Thieperal where a scene of desolation more than any I have seen before, is to be seen.
Entry.94: News to hand of death of Pte Rice, another
Entry.96:
Beautiful day. Have leave to Amiens where I have a good look round, see citadel & the ancient part of the town, which is very interesting. 

Sorry to hear that Harry Bladin has died of wounds.
Entry.97: May Day, beautiful weather at Pozieres.
Entry.98:
Still at Pozieres & mostly practising at cricket in the best of weather.

A very big stunt is about to come off on our front & vague rumours are afloat about the number of men to participate. 

Vote on the General Election for Commonwealth.
Entry.99:
Vague rumours come to hand as to the results of this mornings stunt. Our 2nd Division took their objective, but on their right apparently the English Division which relieved us failed. Still wait for more particulars.

We played & beat the D.S.C. at Albert & they gave us a right royal time.
Entry.100:
Early this morning A & B bearers were sent to the M.D.S. as reserve bearers. We are just outside the village Vaulx-Vraucourt. Apparently there have been a good number of casualties including ambulance men. The result of the attack is that a wedge has been driven into the Hindenburg line.

Beautiful day.
Entry.101: Last night we moved up to the line just behind Riencourt, where a heavy battle is in progress. All night Fritz put up a terrific bombardment & continued it into this morning when I was numbered among the casualties which are very heavy. I think the casualties are heavier also the shelling than at Pozieres.
Entry.102: Through the ordinary channels to & then in Hospital train.
Entry.103: To St Johns Ambulance Brigade Hospital at Etaples.
Entry.104: Still at St Johns Ambulance Brigade Hospital where we are having glorious weather. In my case the M.O. is frightened of bleeding since the bracheal vein has been divided & I cannot be moved to England for about a week.
Entry.105:
From the papers it is apparent that the fighting round Bullecourt & Riencourt is of a very important nature & heavy & mixed fighting seems to be continuous.

The Australians have done all asked of them.
Entry.106: At Etaples yet & the warm weather continues.
Entry.107:
Passed for England

Sister Higgins St John Ambulance B.H. Etaples.
Entry.108: Move to England. Via Calais, Dover to Charing Cross. The railway run in France was beautiful, all the trees in blossom & leaf. Quiet crossing in H.S. Cambria. The strand had not a soul in it at 2.30 am this morning.
Entry.109:
At No. 3 London General Hospital Wandsworthy. 

Still in bed but to get up shortly.
Entry.110: Afternoon at Richmond through a most terrific storm at Mortlake.Blocks were forced up from the roads,houses struck by lightening & much water on the low ground.
Entry.111: Carrel Dakin system of perpetual irrigation to be attached to my arm.
Entry.113: Since last Sunday night I have been in bed in B.4 Ward & looked after O.K. The nurses, VADs are very good
Entry.114:
& the sisters vary. The head sister told me off a treat a few days ago for getting out of bed, but Sister Dobson has already introduced me to a very nice friend, who I think will be a lasting friend, Miss Jelly. The Officer in charge of the ward is Sir Alfred Pearce Gould a very eminent surgeon. 

The weather lately
Entry.115: has been wet & thundery, but now it is again beautiful. Our ward is decorated with very nice flowers tulips, roses & lilac. A character of an outback Australian occupies the bed opposite to mine. He knows Burro & is a typical shearer & the way he speaks to the head sister is very amusing.
Entry.116: Now allowed up in afternoons after my dressings have been done.
Entry.117: The Carrel tubes have now been taken out of my wound which is rapidly healing & I am now allowed up all day.
Entry.118:
Visitors Miss Collings

Ravenslea Road

Wardsworth Common
Entry.119: Afternoon in London at Bank & walk round. Lyons Picadilly Corner House. Meet Trotter now a Lieut in R.A.N. Not allowed to draw money at Bank without permission of Military Auth.
Entry.120: Outing arranged by some lady to Hanky Panky at Empire Theatre & tea.
Entry.121: Visiting day. Capt Hunt & Mr Neave.
Entry.122: Whole day off from 10 am. Spent on the river on an excursion steamer & travelled up as far as Richmond via Barnes Putney Kew etc. The most beautiful of places now is Richmond, far more so than in March.
Entry.123:
News of fresh advance on Messines Ridge where we were last June.

Hospital Sports this afternoon were a great success.
Entry.125: Hinted that I shall go on convalescent soon.
Entry.126: Afternoon drive to Keston Common between Farnborough & Bromley in Kent. We were entertained by & at the home of Mrs Wheeler Bennett which is situated in beautiful grounds. The route out lay past the Chrystal Palace & along the fringe of the Surrey Hills & back, through the suburbs.
Entry.127:
Apparently there was an air raid on London this morning at 11.45. I saw the shells from Archies bursting but not the planes. Rumour says that Bank Cannon St & Ludgate Hill were bombed but know nothing of casualties.

Went before a board this morning & I suppose I will soon be going convalescent. 

Major Wilson & his wife have just been in & they tell me that poor Reg Shergold has died of wounds.
Entry.128:
In yesterdays raid over four hundred wounded & ninety killed & much damage done.

Drive & outing to Box Hill Surrey where we had tea at Burford Bdge Hotel. A great day Surrey with its villages roads, fields, hills & trees like Kent baffles all adjectives of description. The most beautiful imagineable.
Entry.129: Beautiful weather still. Fine concert this evening figuring Mr Theo Ward musical advisor to Sir Thos Wyndham & artists from London Theatres
Entry.130:
A day in London. At Shaftesbury Theatre "Il Trovatore" by the Carl Rosa Opera Co. not as good a company as Quinlan.

Further hints at going convalescent.
Entry.131: Afternoon at Richmond through most terrific thunder storm.
Entry.132: Secretary for Colonies Mr Walter Long spoke this evening to the men.
Entry.133: Not to go to Dartford, but to come here, Holborn Military Hospital Mitcham has been my convalescent. The only decent thing about the place is a permanent daily pass. Otherwise it is rotten.
Entry.136: I have come to the conclusion that this alleged hospital is at the lowest ebb as regards the conditions of food & general affairs. The district is filthy & I will be pleased to get out of it.
Entry.137: I have asked to be discharged on Friday.
Entry.138:
Discharged from Hospital & receive pass for 14 days furlough.

"Maid of the Mountains" at Dalys. Weather wet & generally miserable but things are OK. It is good to have meals at your own time etc.
Entry.139: Richmond this afternoon after going to the Bank this morning
Entry.140: Hampton Court on the river & later at Richmond. The river at Hampton Court is very beautiful & some of the side drains especially nice.
Entry.141: Torquay Devonshire at last. The run 200 miles in 4 ½ hours is most glorious. At "Kister" Somerset is particularly nice as well as Devon. We stopped at Westbury, Taunton, Exeter & Newton Abbott.
Entry.142: Torquay is a beautiful town, situated on the shores of Tor, bay, & presents from the bay a very fine aspect. Its houses, fine as they are rise up tier after tier from the shore & are almost hidden from view by the very heavy foliage. The coast is particularly rough, the cliffs being of red
Entry.143:
sandstone. The "Princess Gardens", pier & pavilion are also very nice.

Devonshire cream & fruit need a chapter by themselves.

At Cockington, I saw peaches, figs, grapes tomatoes, cucumbers & melons grown under huge glass houses, in the "Fruit Garden"
Entry.144: Further west is the seaside resort of Paignton, smaller than Torquay yet equally as beautiful. In fact it is purely a place for pleasure & it has been built with that idea. Dellers Café is very chic & the music also very nice.
Entry.145:
For the last week I have been having a most glorious time in & about Torquay, Oddicombe Baltacombe, Cockington Paignton.

At Cockington the house of the old family of Cockingtons, the church, village & fruit garden are most interesting. Along the coast the scenery is grand made
Entry.146: up of red cliffs. Tennis with a couple of girls at the house is the mornings recreation. Great air raid on London to-day & wild rumours reach us as to its severity. Dellers Café at Paignton is unique. One of the most remarkable things about Torquay is that there are two gum trees growing & doing well & tropical palms also down
Entry.147:
Return to London & visit Mrs Caper 

Clapham Common
Entry.148: Off to Birmingham tonight & stay for the night at the Grand Hotel. Birmingham is a very busy place, but is made up of nearly all industrial houses. Some of the suburbs are very nice
Entry.149:
Walk round the Black Country which in the vastness of its works is a revelation to me. See Lea-Brook Wednesbury Bilston Smithwick & have indeed an interesting time. 

"Catch of the Season" at the theatre.
Entry.150: Back in London. Stay at Strand Palace Hotel.
Entry.151:
At the Opera this evening. Tristram & Islode at Drury Lane which is gorgeous. Go to camp at Perham Downs tomorrow.

Tea with Mrs Capes, Clapham Com.
Entry.152:
In camp at Perham Downs. It is pretty rotten being back in camp after having the last two months in luxury comparatively.

However things are not too bad & the food is eatable.
Entry.153: The country about here is made up of undulating downs dotted here & there with woods & villages & on the
Entry.154: whole just now is very pretty, especially in the woods. I am debating within myself as to whether I should apply for a com & if augmenting my chances of being killed or wounded, at least being able to live decently & get out of this rotten life.
Entry.155:
Still here doing nothing & enjoying books and fine weather. One book Ernest Maltravers by Lytton has impressed me very much.

I have continued my walkings about the country & have found some
Entry.156:
very pleasant spots.

This Commission business has a good hold of my mind
Entry.157: Visit the neighbouring town of Andover which is very slow & quiet
Entry.159: Warned to move to another part of the camp tomorrow.
Entry.161: Command Depot, a hundred yards or so, where I believe we will go through preliminary training
Entry.162:
Training in earnest, physical jerks etc & I think I will enjoy it, even though it is taking perspiration out of me.

Loafing about makes one sluggish & the jerks are just what I need.
Entry.163: Still in No 3 camp, No 1 Command depot where we are doing physical jerks & route marches daily. Saw Barnby Brown to-day
Entry.164: Concert at Y.M.C.A. by Lena Ashwell. Very decent, classical
Entry.167:
Tonight I spent very pleasantly, in a old Pozieres gathering Docker & Barnby & also James & Robby were there & we had a good talk over old times.

I don’t know, but in spite of paper talk etc I think peace movements are getting a hold.
Entry.168:
If this country & the people are realizing the utter absurdity of driving Germany out of Belgium & France. Soon too, think we will compromise with Germany perhaps this year, as an outcome of this peace feeling.

Wattle day at home

Third battle of Ypres began yesterday & has been made out to be a huge success. 

What are our casualties in these stunts?
Entry.169:
Change in the weather which up to yesterday was beautiful is now wet cold & windy.

Three very interesting lectures this morning on "Economy in War Time" principally. Also on the eternal topics.
Entry.170: To go by coach with Dock & Barnby to Salisbury tomorrow.
Entry.171: Salisbury trip cried off on account of bad weather & Barnby not being able to come.
Entry.172: Beginning of 4th year of war & still no prospect of "victorious" ending though prospects of a compromise
Entry.173: Beautiful day. Walk to Appleshaw through most beautiful private grounds with Cotterell
Entry.174: Move to another part of camp where after having my teeth attended to, I will be "fit for France".
Entry.175:
Twenty two to-day.

In to-days paper I notice that Capt Aspinal has been killed in action. He was a fine chap & his loss will be deeply felt.
Entry.176: Walk round a few villages about made up of thatched cottages etc. & pretty garden
Entry.177: At dentists one tooth out & three filled which finishes the contract.
Entry.178:
Have come the proverbial "gutser" & am now marked as A3 meaning medically & dentally fit for France.

Move to another camp
Entry.179:
Move from command depot to Overseas Training Brigade from where infantry go on draft to France.

We still have to go to our depot at Park House before crossing over.
Entry.180: Rehearsal for big review on Monday next
Entry.181: Mess Orderly for guard & detention a rotten job
Entry.182: Met Bob Goldrick now Capt in this camp. Leaves for France on Tuesday.
Entry.183:
The troops about here, including O.T.B. have been inspected by H.R.H. Duke of Connaught. 

The review was a success

On account of my 6’2" of length I was given a rifle & put in front line of Battalion.
Entry.184: Warned for draft to Park House.
Entry.185: Letter from Dock that he can get me in the AQMGs office. H.Q.
Entry.186:
Move to Park House, A.M.C. Depot. The camp is very good.

Dock says I will be ‘phoned for tomorrow to take up duties at A.Q.M.Gs office Tidworth
Entry.187: Interview with officer at AQMGs office & I am to be taken on the staff.
Entry.188: Letter from Dock that everything has gone wrong & that I cannot get into the offices.
Entry.189: Up till late the weather has been very unsettled raining off & on every day but now we are having beautifully warm days.
Entry.190: Walk all over the country to Wallop on the Southampton road. The country & villages & especially the trees about here are beautiful & this is Salisbury Plain
Entry.191: Still walking the countryside of an evening.
Entry.192: The new arrivals from Australia have been responsible for introducing the meningitis germ into this camp & a section of it is isolated. One or two cases have been diagnosed as C.B.M. & there are many suspects of carrying
Entry.193:
Warned for draft to France.

Barnby is engaged to be married.
Entry.194:
Medical exams etc preparatory to going on draft.

The divisions in France are still out of the line & have been so for the past four months, since Bullecourt.
Entry.195: The equipping & examinations of the draft have been completed & we expect to move any moment. We have parades every few hours to assure out not being out of camp.
Entry.196: The weather is beautiful but the pack is heavy.
Entry.197: Still training for draft to France & dancing about the country with packs.
Entry.199:
in my army career.

We are under marching orders & tomorrow we move over to France. The O.C. is giving a supper tonight.

Meet Major Wilson on the road.
Entry.200: This morning we entrained at Tidworth & arrived at Southhampton before noon. All day we have been mixing with the Americans who are going over on our boat.
Entry.201: Last night we left Southampton Water at 7.30 & by cleared the Solent & saw the last of the Isle of Wight at about 10 o’clock. We arrived at Harve this morning at 2.30 & at 7 we marched off to our camp at Harfleur about 8 kilos from Harve. So far I haven’t seen the town of Harve but the docks are very extensive. Harfleur looks rather interesting being of course noted for Henry 5th’s speech.
Entry.202: Day spent at gas school on a hill over Harfleur, round which the Seine runs. The river here is large, but with marshy foreshores & there is much navigation of it. This part is very pretty about the hills, in fact much like England. The weather is beautiful but Autumn is coming judging from the colouring of the trees.
Entry.203:
Visit Le Havre. The town of 150000 is a large sea port & the harbour is large but artificial. L’hotel de Ville & Theatre are the best of the buildings.

The suburb of St Addresse is very fine & appears to be the select residential part of town. It has a large beach, dotted with bathing machines & boasts of a casino etc. in keeping with usual French coastal resorts. Rue de Gallion.
Entry.204:
Warned for draft.

A particularly fine Lena Ashwell concert party at YMCA this night.
Entry.205: Move to Havre,from whichwe expect to depart at about1 am tomorrow.
Entry.206:
Have just cleared out of camp,evaded the MP’s & got to the spire of the cathedral.Spire too much.Panorama simply magnificent of the river and town.

We are now at Rouen in rest camps along the banks of the Seine. The river here is crowded with barge & towing traffic & the banks are lined with factories. I have just had a glimpse of the cathedral which is fine the main feature being the spire. As usual it is much bigger than any other bldgs
Entry.207:
Move from Rouen at 10 pm after 14 hours stay to Caestre between Hazebrouck Poperinghe via Amiens, Albert Achut Arras St Pol & Hazebrouck. Journey not to comfortable

Monday 24

Back to Steenvoorde where we were this time last year about. We marched from Caestre to here yesterday morning & spent the day & night in 1st Div Reinforcement Camp. Expect to join unit tomorrow.

The 4th Battle of Ypres opened a few days back & the Australians are in the thick of it. The 1st Div advance about a mile with only 2000 odd casualties.
Entry.209: Arrive at unit at Steenvoorde to find only nursing section here. The ambulance is much changed & the officers are mostly new.
Entry.210: Walk to Cassel but did not see much of the town
Entry.211: The afternoon at Abeele to have a look for Geo. Peterson, failed to find him
Entry.212:
There is certainly a war in progress on the Ypres front & ambulance casualties are usually at about 30% to 50% equally as heavy as infantry.

The bombardments are very violent & these moonlit nights favour nightly aerial work on both sides.
Entry.213:
Another walk to Cassel & back by the great moonlight which we are enjoying now. The weather has been glorious while here, fine days & moonlit nights.

We are moving up to A.D.S. tomorrow. The artillery fire has been very intense of late
Entry.214: Move from Steenvoorde to Dickebusch partly by foot & partly by motor through Poperinghe Camp for a while in Buren Chateau where we were in the centre of a Fritz bombing stunt.
Entry.215: Move up to the line through Ypres on the Menin road where the fighting lately has been very severe. The ground is broken up very much & the roads back are lined with dead men & animal. The shelling just now is moderate.
Entry.216: Very busy day on left of Menin Road at R.A.P. & other posts. The system of practice barrages is being adopted two very heavy ones daily taking place. Fritz counter attacked tonight & his barrage was very heavy. Held up by it for about two hours. Post is being heavily shelled & it is decided to move it up to safer position. A battery blown out above us.
Entry.217: Move back to Dickebush through Ypres. Pass the ruins of Cloth Hall & other buildings. No building has more than a few bricks left to mark it. I suppose this battle will be called
Entry.218:
Battle of Ypres or Menin Road. Another attack takes place tomorrow & elaborate preparations are being made for it

From accounts it will be the final objective of the battle the ridge commanding a great amount of flat country & hazards any coastal enterprises of Fritz. The dead in horses & men is enormous, especially well back

Thursday 4

Move back through Ypres to Nestock ridge & thence to forward posts of the new advance. It has been raining & the place has been converted into a veritable quagmire. 

The advance this morning was entirely successfull & to-nights counter attack was repulsed. Zonnebeke was taken 
last night
 this morn.
Entry.219: At forward posts of new advance where we up to our knees in mud. The carrying is very heavy & long. The shelling is very severe, nearly all 5.9 & over. Our casualties have been heavy & since the ambulance has been on this sector 13 killed including Major Hunt & about 30 wounded, including many old boys.
Entry.220:
Not much work today & it has been showery. Two more casualties have resulted bringing total to 45. Morris was killed.

Move to Garber point for night
Entry.221: Move back to Dickebush for next 24 hours. The weather is awful, wet, & the conditions up the line must be worse than previously.
Entry.222: Spend day at Dickebush & tonight we move up to Westhoek tunnell. We are due for a stunt in the morning but the more important part of it is on our left to the sea.
Entry.223: The result of this mornings stunt is successful. The artillery on our side is very active but Fritz is comparatively silent. In a great air duel one Fritz decended in flames & one of ours came down. The airman came through our post but was dead. From the artillery just now 6 p.m. a counter attack is in progress.
Entry.224:
Move back to about 4 Kilos north of Poperinghe. What is exactly in the wind I know not but rumour has it that we move from this area.

The Australian part of this last stunt was a great success & now all the high ridge commanding all the surrounding country is in our hands.

The treatment the 1st Field meets out to its men is anything than a credit to the unit regards food, clothes & general.
Entry.225:
The weather we are now having gives evidence of the rapid approach of winter, raining off & on daily.

Visit Poperinghe & see Eric Greenwell. Poperinghe is much the same as last year but in darkness. Enemy aerial activity
Entry.226: Visit Rininghilst. Weather still wet & miserable
Entry.227:
Nothing of importance the last few days.

The clear nights are favourable to bombing on both sides. Fritz comes over & about us last night & to-night he has been very active
Entry.228: German Aeroplanes are detected at night by the pecular, irregular throbbing of their engines. The searchlights are not at all quick in picking them up & usually the guns in the vicinity of the bombing object are first to discover him. When they are caught in the light they look very fine.
Entry.229:
In an aerial battle this morning one German plane came down in flames from a great height.

German planes have been very active during the nights & mornings & they have been dropping many bombs about the neighborhood
Entry.230: The guns on the front have been very active, both English & Germans
Entry.231: Visit the little coffee shop on Poperinghe Reninghelst road where there was a motley crowd all singing various songs Belgian girls Australians Canadians Chinese of Chinese Labour corps & West Indians. The evening was very merry & the coffee good. A German plane flew very low all over the ground, but it is rumoured that it was brought down
Entry.232: Poperinghe & the picture show where we saw an Australian Gazette. It is a pity the authorities don’t send more of these over to the front to keep the boys in touch with events at Home.
Entry.233:
German planes bombed very close to the camp this morning.

Move most likely tomorrow
Entry.234: Visit Poperinghe & see "The Duds" & English variety show. Renenghelst was bombed by Fritz last night
Entry.235: Another trip to Poperinghe and to the "Anchor Follies" which are not at all bad. We move tomorrow to Lille Gate Ypres to be in reserve for 2nd Field Ambulance.
Entry.236:
Move this morning to Ypres "The city of Fear" and camp in dugouts at Lille Gate. The dugouts are made in the ramparts and are long tunnels lit with electricity, like baby road tunnels.

Fritz’s Gothas came over the town this afternoon & received no opposition.

Met George Wilkie. I believe we join on left of our old position, through Frezenberg
Entry.237:
Still at Lille Gate Ypres waiting in reserve. Things are quiet on the line.

Rumours of a stunt tomorrow are about, on a big scale
Entry.238:
Still at Lille Gate Ypres. Last night bombing activity by Fritz & to-day big shells which made our dugout rock like a ship.

Move up the line in the morning.

Yesterday morning the Canadians took Paschendale ridge, but owing to the heavy shell fire had to abandon it
Entry.239: Move up early this morning to Zonnebeke now about 1 mile behind the line. The post is located in a cordial factory & is fairly shell proof. Fritz has been shelling very heavily about here with very big stuff. The day has been fine & cares few so except for the magnetism of the place things aren’t bad.
Entry.240: A carry last night brought us back along the Ypres to Zonnebeke road where we have been in a fine big pill box for the day. Shelling heavy. Very few casualties.
Entry.241: Still at R.H.Q. on Zonnebeke Road near Fryenberg. Very few cases are coming through though the shelling in the back areas is very heavy including many gas shells. One carry to the Canadian aid post was very warm. Fritz is getting on to our batteries after news of German offensive on Italy.
Entry.242:
Heavy gas attack last night by shelling. A carry through it and a fall into a shell hole were the nights episode.

A Canadian attack this morning at about 6 am resulted in the Canadians obtaining all objectives in vicinity of Paschendale ridge. Relieved this afternoon by third F.A. & come back to Lille Gate.
Entry.243: Will’s birthday. A beautiful day in Ypres at Lille Gate where things are very quiet. The Canadians still hang to the positions they took yesterday
Entry.244:
An ordinary day at Lille Gate.

More disconcerting news from Italy
Entry.245: A trip to Poperinghe for the day
Entry.246:
Nothing at all to record.

Tuesday 6

A very hot carry down from Zonnebeke, perhaps hottest I have yet had. Caffin’s squad had a patient killed on stretcher & an accussation made by an officer at R.A.P. (Zonnebeke) is to be looked into.
Entry.247:
A concert troupe at Deckebusch.

Move up to Zonnebeke tomorrow again.

Meet Bill Sutton
Entry.248:
Move up to Zonnebeke again.

Going in the shelling in parts was severe, but at the R.A.P. things are very quiet. One carry to Pill Box at Railway Dugout was very hot in parts. A Canadian attack on Paschendale within 48 hrs Italian news still very bad. 200,000 men 1800 guns
Entry.249: From all accounts this mornings stunt was entirely successful the village of Paschendale being in Canadian hands. It is to be hoped that they can hang to it. Very few Australian casualties. Often bad luck still follows us & this morning we had three killed & one badly wounded. "Snowy" Walters was among the killed, a fine little chap. (cp. Sat. 3rd)
Entry.250: Nothing special. At Potsdam Train on the Roulus railway. The shelling still continues heavy
Entry.251:
Move back to Dickebusch via Ypres & re-join the unit. We move from this area shortly for a good spell.

News of the loss of an outgoing mail.
Entry.252:
At Dickebusch. Weather wet & miserable.

Move on Sunday morning probably to Renescure near St Omer

The funeral of "Snowy" Waters etc who were killed in last stunt
Entry.253:
Wet weather & still at Wickebusch.

Transport moved to-day & we move tomorrow in char-a- bancs
Entry.254: Move by motor bus to Renescure, 7 Kilos east of St Omer. The way lay via Poperinghe, Stienvorde & Cassel & the weather, not being bad, allowed the day to be enjoyed.
Entry.255: Camped at Renescure. A walk to St Omer in the afternoon & a good look over the town. The most interesting part of the place is in L’Abbaye St Bertin which is almost in ruins. Move on again tomorrow, about a 14 miles march. The route lay along Cassel – St Omer through Arques. Mail, Home,
Entry.256:
A great march from Renescure to a village near Duonville on Rolougne-Arras road 30 kilos from the Coast. The day was beautiful & we marched light through Arques along Rte Pab 28, St Omer – Abbeville to Clity & then to the right to Duonville. About 8 miles. Partly our way lay through the Valley of L’Aa past some chalk quarries. The trees now are losing their foliage it is forming a colour carpet about the bases of the trees. What leaves are still on the trees are beautiful in their Autumn tints

1stly the country agricultural kilo

2ndly beautiful agricultural country & very hilly
Entry.257:
In billets at Ecuire near Duonville. A mornings walk along L’Aa to Thiembronne & in the afternoon to Fauquembergue also on the Aa a distance of about 8 kilos. 

The country, undulating & terraced is chiefly agricultural growing wheat & sugar beet. The town is a fair size
Entry.258: Nothing of special interest. Move most likely tomorrow in the direction of Bolougne
Entry.259: No move to-day on account of the inability to find billets. Our officers (some) showed some very gentlemanly conduct last night en route from Bolougne
Entry.260: Move from Ecuire to a farm house between Coursel & Course near Desures, Sainer & about 20 kilos from Bolougne. Weather grey
Entry.261:
Putting up tents etc & other fatigues incident to making a permanent camp. 

Leave is open to Bolougne. Weather still grey.

Mail
Entry.262:
Ordinary day in billet routine fatigues etc. 

Weather still bad. Pay day
Entry.263: Bad weather still. Visit town of Desures.
Entry.264: Ordinary day except that Madame’s fowls have suffered. The catching & dispensing of them caused much amusement. Visit Bolougne on leave tomorrow.
Entry.265: Leave to Bolougne. Travel from Coursel, via Desures & Werevynes. The road is a succession of hills culminating in Mt Lambeth overlooking the town. L’Eyline Notre Dame & Bolougne is on top, very prominent. Visit Weivereux & have a look at fishermen & women at work on quay. Arrive home at 11 pm.
Entry.266:
Bath in open baths at Cement Works in warm water, 5 feet deep. Quite a decent swim.

Sunday 25

1st Madames cider 2nd her apples
Entry.267: her fowls & now we are having her potatoes mashed nightly. Tresbon. First snow to-day. Heavy winds & rain.
Entry.268:
Quite surprisingly comes the order that we are moving tomorrow to Courcolette, five or seven kilos from Boulgne.

To-day has been beautifuly fine.
Entry.269:
Early this morning we were on loudery fatigue in the mud & rain & pulling down tents, but for the move it kept fine. Marched along R.N. No 1 through Samer & about 9 kilos from Boulogne we turned to the 
left
 right for a mile or so. We are now billeted in the farm building of a rather big house, in fact the best billets we have been in in France.

R.N. No 1 Montrierch – Boulogne – Calais.
Entry.270:
Work mostly fixing up new camp. These billets are very comfortable & the farm building etc are much better than any we have been in previously.

The view from the hilltop is fine commanding undulating valleys including that of La Laine River. We have seen practically all that river.
Entry.271:
A rest camp is to be opened by the ambulance & tents have been erected this afternoon.

An aleyed dinner tonight resulted in the potatoes not being cooled. Our cooks are up to putty.
Entry.272: Wet today but the discomfiture was counteracted by a big mail & pay
Entry.274: Walk to Pont de Briques about 6 kilos from Boulogne on the main road. Wind very heavy and cold.
Entry.275:
First freeze of the season this morning & by the look of the sky & the feel of the wind it will be encore tomorrow morning. Another walk over the hills & through Pont de Briques. Sunny.

Xmas mail is arriving
Entry.276: A beautifully fine but very cold day. Another heavy frost.
Entry.277:
Another fine day & cold.

This afternoon I took a train ride from Pont des Briques to Hardelot on the sea, south of Boulogne. It is a fine watering place with a nice beach, tiled promenade, tennis courts etc. The houses are modern 
billets
 villas and look very nice.

The wood, planted in the dunes is fine & mostly of pine trees. On the route is an old castle where Henry VIII lived while the Field of the Cloth of Gold was on. A fine old house in Pont des Briques is where Napoleon 1st planned his Austerlitz Campaign 1805-6.

In fact the whole place abounds in historical interest. At Ardres (Sept 16.) the Camp of the Field of the Cloth of Gold
Entry.278: A dinner last night at Pont des Briques for the B Section. The repast was sumptuous & the tables nicely decorated with holly. A sing song after & the feeling O.K. we all went home
Entry.280: Batt in which Ambulance was defeated
Entry.283:
Beautiful day. A dinner tonight was very decent.

Rumours are about that we move back to the line at Messines in a couple of days
Entry.284: Weather is still fine. We perhaps move on Saturday morning to somewhere in the vicinity of Loere but the journey is to be accomplished in stages.
Entry.285: Move to-day at sunrise to Senleques via Samer for Reserves. A beautiful day & a decent
Entry.286: Move from Senleques to Warrams. Snowing tonight & prospects of more tomorrow.
Entry.287: A very cold night last night. Move today to Wizernes & there entrain, disentrain at Ballieul & thence to Danoutre, about ten kilos behind the line at Messines. The bombardment on the left, Ypres is fairly heavy
Entry.288: Rumour has it that the Germans are going to make an attack on this front. Certainly the artillery is very active, day & night.
Entry.289: A very heavy hoar frost to-day & tonight & the hedges etc are covered with frost crystal. No rain & the ponds etc are frozen over
Entry.290: Visit Ballieul again. The town is the same as of old. French customs are queer. To-day I saw a man carrying an empty coffin under one arm & the cross under the other. The effect of this hoar frost is just fairy like, beautiful.
Entry.291: Visit 9th Field Ambulance& have tea with Verne Cocks & quite a good yarn. En route passed through old haunts, Neuve Eglise & Steenwerck. Still freezing
Entry.292: Mr. Winkler never cut a better figure on the ice than I did to-day on a pond. Nearly came several croppers but never mind. Beautiful weather
Entry.293: "B" Section’s dinner last night was a complete success for Xmas.
Entry.294:
2 pm. Snowing to-day & typically English. I have just seen the patients dinner dished out & everything turned out well. Patients all well pleased. Our meal tonight.

The Dinner was O.K. but no one felt inclined for the concert after. The officers were in a snow fight for us & were rolled over & over in it. Some Xmas.
Entry.295:
Still more snow, heavy. Not over the effects of last night yet.

Yesterday, hardly a shot was heard & everything was peaceful, with the snow all over the ground.

Heavy bombardment tonight German I think
Entry.296:
Snow still on the ground.

Walk to Caestre to-day.

A Section Bearers is up the line for raid. Roads very slippery & many wagons motor & horse have been ditched as a result.
Entry.297:
A visit from Fritz by aeroplane this morning and a couple of bombs dropped near by.

The Kookaburras are here again & the girl is better than ever
Entry.299:
Prospects of to-morrow nights performance is promising (?)

No mail for ages from Home.
Entry.300:
Fine day & snowing at night.

Artillery activity is marked & a Fritz plane has been over.

The gathering in the hut is complete & among them there is much licquor. Bagpipes, songs etc are the orders and it has eventually ended at midnight with "Old Lang Syne" & an orgy. I myself am O.K. & have put a few of them to bed. The officers lost any 
spark
 of dignity they ever possessed. Welcomed the men into the mess for the New Year.

When I look back at 1917 I find it has been adventurous & educating. The winter on the Somme was bad enough & the Battles of Bullicourt & Ypres rank among the most severe on the front. Two trips to England have in me satisfied a great desire to see & as well as possible that country.
